docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Hormones in milk cause early puberty. THE FACTS -- In 1997, when a large study found that girls were starting puberty sooner than usual, many Americans began to cast a suspicious eye on milk. Could artificial growth hormones that had been widely used on cows since 1993 be speeding development in children? Sales of organic dairy products took off rapidly, but newer studies have found no link. Instead, if girls are maturing sooner, a notion some scientists still dispute, it may have more to do with obesity than milk.
docs.abstract: Research shows no evidence of link between hormones found in cow's milk and early onset of puberty in girls; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Could artificial growth hormones that had been widely used on cows since 1993 be speeding development in children?

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent survey of 559 women in college found that 5 percent had undergone cosmetic surgery, and the most common objective was better looking skin. A more significant concern of the women, however, appeared to be their weight, even when it was not above the norms. When surgery was involved, the treatments were ''mainly chemical peels for acne scars and blemishes,'' said Dr. David B. Sarwer, an associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, and the lead author of the paper.
docs.abstract: Dr David B Sarwer, University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine associate psychiatry professor, leads study on cosmetic surgery among college women; study shows that 44 percent of those surveyed approve of cosmetic surgery, but 88 percent said they would not undergo procedure at request of their partner; study was published in journal Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A recent survey of 559 women in college found that 5 percent had undergone cosmetic surgery, and the most common objective was better looking skin.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most musicians have to work hard to learn to identify musical intervals, two notes of a scale played at the same time. But a musician described in the current issue of Nature can actually taste tone intervals, and some taste better than others. Synesthesia, a puzzling sensory phenomenon in which a sound evokes an experience of color (the sound of a truck ''looks green'') or a sight evokes a sound (a light coming on ''sounds like a bell'') is well known, though rare.

headline.main: Sweet and Sour Tones For the Record Books

docs.abstract: Synesthesia, uncommon sensory phenomemon in which one sense evokes secondary sensory experience, rarely involves taste or smell; Dr Michaela Esslen of University of Zurich describes musician who experiences flavors in direct correlation with musical intervals; less pleasing tones accompany flavors that are less pleasant and sweet tones most often have good flavor; research is published in journal Nature (M)
docs.snippet: A musician described in the current issue of Nature can actually taste tone intervals, and some taste better than others.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study published in the March issue of Biological Psychology suggests that the shorter a man's index finger is compared with his ring finger, the more physically aggressive he is likely to be. It has been known for more than 100 years that men, unlike women, usually have ring fingers longer than their index fingers.

headline.main: What Else His Ring Finger Says

docs.abstract: Allison A Bailey, University of Alberta psychology graduate student, leads study that suggests correlation between finger length and aggressiveness in males; research, which is published in journal Biological Psychology, finds that men with index fingers that are considerable shorter than their ring fingers test high for physical aggressiveness; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that the shorter a man's index finger is compared with his ring finger, the more physically aggressive he is likely to be.

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents of wailing babies, take comfort: you are not alone. Chimpanzee babies fuss. Sea gull chicks squawk. Burying beetle larvae tap their parents' legs. Throughout the animal kingdom, babies know how to get their parents' attention. Exactly why evolution has produced all this fussing, squawking and tapping is a question many biologists are now trying to answer. Someday, that answer may shed some light on the mystery of colic in human babies.

headline.main: A Darwinian Look at a Wailing Baby

docs.abstract: Throughout animal kingdom babies get attention from their parents or caregivers by either physically or verbally making fuss; Dr Joseph Soltis, Disney's Animal Kingdom bioacoustics expert who recently published article on evolution of crying in journal Behavioral and Brain Sciences, asserts that study of animal babies may lead to better understanding of excessive crying in human babies that is often attributed to colic; various theories about crying in infants and animal babies discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Parents of wailing babies, take comfort: you are not alone.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine have tested a gel that when applied topically in the vagina, may help prevent infection by both H.I.V. and herpes simplex virus. AIDS researchers have long sought such a microbicide. Dr. Marla J. Keller, a professor of medicine and the lead author on the study, presented the data at the 12th Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections in Boston on Feb. 24.

headline.main: Gel for Safer Sex Shows Promise

docs.abstract: Dr Marla J Keller of Mount Sinai School of Medicine leads research on vaginal gel, which may help prevent HIV and herpes simplex viral infections; details of study involving 20 HIV-infected women were presented at Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections Conference (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors have tested a gel that when applied topically in the vagina, may help prevent infection by both H.I.V. and herpes simplex virus.

docs.lead_paragraph: I recently cared for a woman who insisted on wearing her own pajamas throughout her hospitalization. She also brought along her own quilt and pillowcase, ate her own food (brought from home or a nearby deli by her husband) and kept her own stuffed brown bear nearby. I am usually a sucker for such low-grade insurrection. After all, on a bad day, a hospital resembles nothing so much as a penal colony.

headline.main: An Insurrection on the Mighty Ship of Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Kent A Sepkowitz Cases column discusses difficult balancing act doctors often maintain when working with patients who are ill; asserts that preserving hope can be critical component of care; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Why fantasy and life-and-death dramas don't mix.

docs.lead_paragraph: The dozens of letters, phone calls and e-mail messages I've received since writing my recent columns on total knee replacement and pain management reveal that I struck a chord. Some readers chastised me for scaring potential patients away from this surgery, which, when healing is completed, can greatly enhance quality of life. But many others praised me for ''telling it like it is'' about an often painful and difficult recovery that surgeons don't warn patients about.

headline.main: A Fight for Full Disclosure of the Possible Pain

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses post-operative pain from knee replacement surgery; calls for doctors to tell patients truth about what recovery period may entail and allow them to make educated decision about operation; column holds that without adequate information patients cannot plan for future and prepare for recovery; overall problems with approach to pain management discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Sharing lessons from painful recoveries from knee surgery.

docs.lead_paragraph: Laughter may be good for your heart. A new study demonstrates that laughing causes the tissue that forms the inner lining of blood vessels, the endothelium, to expand and thereby increase blood flow -- exactly what aerobic exercise does. In a study presented yesterday at the meeting of the American College of Cardiology in Orlando, researchers had 20 healthy volunteers watch a 15-minute segment from ''Kingpin,'' a 1996 Woody Harrelson comedy, and then 48 hours later view the opening battle scene from ''Saving Private Ryan,'' the 1998 war movie starring Tom Hanks.

headline.main: Go On, Laugh Your Heart Out

docs.abstract: Dr Michael Miller leads study that finds laughter is beneficial to heart health; study, in which volunteers watched funny movies, showed that laughing increased blood flow similar to levels brought on by aerobic activity; study was presented at meeting of American College of Cardiology; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study may demonstrate the old adage that laughter is good for your heart.

docs.lead_paragraph: How would you like that symbol, doc? One snake or two? On Jan. 25, a drawing in Science Times showed a patient borne aloft by the caduceus -- the wand of the Greek god Hermes, or Mercury to the Romans, entwined by two snakes and topped by wings.

headline.main: Slithery Medical Symbolism: Worm or Snake? One or Two?

docs.abstract: Symbols Asklepian, which uses one snake, and caduceus, which has two snakes, are used to represent medical profession; background of and opinions on each symbol discussed; drawings (M)
docs.snippet: How would you like that symbol, doc? One snake or two?
